body: The views are not commanding, unless you count the one of the exhaust stations for the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel. Yet champions of the Brooklyn Motor Inn say it is a promising idea for a new hotel in New York for an unlikely reason: it's in Red Hook. ''We've got everything you need right here,'' said Sal Faraone, manager of the Motor Inn, speaking
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RED HOOK; In Area Where Capone Roamed, Inn Burnishes a Changing Image

body: Lord Falconer of Thoroton, the highest-ranking judicial official in Britain, visited the Midtown Community Court yesterday and pronounced himself ''utterly delighted.'' It would probably be safe to argue that he was the first lord to visit the state's little community court, and the noblest dignitary ever to be so happy to walk in the steps of New
title: A Dignitary Examines Community Court

body: In running away with Hollywood, is the Brooklyn Navy Yard running away from its proletarian past? The concrete walls of Steiner Studios, a $118 million project under construction in a cinematic Navy Yard locale on the Brooklyn waterfront, are climbing ever higher and the first of five soundstages is scheduled to open next fall. Its owners hope it
title: Disquiet on the Set; At Navy Yard, It's Hollywood vs. a Blue-Collar Past

body: Jonathan P. Luna, a federal prosecutor in Baltimore whose body was found in rural Pennsylvania on Thursday, was stabbed 36 times and may have been tortured before he was thrown into a creek to drown, officials said on Friday. Mr. Luna's body was discovered near the town of Ephrata, south of Reading, Pa., on Thursday morning, hours before he was
title: Torture Is Possible in Prosecutor's Death

body: To the Editor: Re ''Nightmare on Bay 53rd St.: From Dead End to Detour'' (Nov. 9), about the Home Depot in White Sands, Brooklyn: People have been worried about big-box stores since they first arrived in New York City. The only way to allay community worries about issues like traffic is to put these mega-stores right off highways, not on local
title: Big-Box Stores: Dangers and Remedies

body: The city is dangling the prospect of up to $10 million in city bank deposits for banks and other financial institutions to encourage them to open branches in neighborhoods with few or no branches. Under the program, which was announced yesterday, banks that accept the municipal deposits will pay the city a reduced interest rate, but will offer
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: City To Promote Bank Services

body: FOIST of all, let's make one pernt poifectly clear: they don't talk like this in Brooklyn. At least most of them don't. And they didn't even back when they did, if you'll forgive the Yogi-ism. At least most of them didn't, not the way filmmakers would have had you believe over the decades, with all those on-screen characters turning oys into ers
title: NYC; Not Poifect, Dem Movies Of Brooklyn

body: James Parks, on his knees, struggled to find the one screw amid the 20,000 parts that would unjam the scraped and dented New York City voting machine he was repairing. Ray Crews, another mechanic, had a handful of thin metal straps, which he carefully threaded, one at a time, into the back of the 800-pound behemoth he was servicing nearby. And
title: Vote Machine Replacement Lags, Despite Age

body: Word on the street was that some big-shot wiseguys from New Jersey were going to be doing a little business down by the Brooklyn waterfront yesterday, so Joseph Fazzia stepped out in front of his warehouse to scope things out. You know Joey, the guy who runs the school bus contracting establishment down there in Red Hook and wears that gold chain
title: Sopranos Muscle In on the Red Hook Waterfront

body: WE are a city of heroes. The rest of the country may clamor for po' boys and hoagies, grinders, subs, wedges or torpedoes, but New York knows what really constitutes a gigantic sandwich, and what raises the hero above those pretenders; what makes it gastronomic royalty. Let there be no misunderstanding by those who have never ventured to New York,
title: Hey, Po' Boy, Meet Some Real Heroes

body: The immense water tunnel -- known officially as City Tunnel No. 3 -- has been so long in the making that its construction has already outlasted five mayors, inspired thousands of news stories and killed 23 tunnel workers. And it still will not be finished for at least another 17 years. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg pulled on rubber boots and a yellow
title: Mayor Goes 550 Feet Below to Note Start of Tunnel Construction

body: There are plenty of ways to find restaurant reviews in New York, from a glut of guidebooks to elaborate Web sites to leaning over the railing of a sidewalk cafe to ask if the portobello omelet is up to snuff. But Mark Hurst, a Hell's Kitchen resident who runs an Internet consulting company and was happy with none of the above, decided to let New
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK FOOD; Grappling Gourmets Are Doing Battle On a New Web Site

body: I DREAM about finding restaurants like 360, a storefront in Red Hook, Brooklyn, where passion, generosity, commitment, eccentricity and skill outweigh any semblance of good common sense. No committee could ever plan a place like 360, no focus group would ever endorse it, and at the end of the day, no group of shareholders would ever approve it. The
title: $25 AND UNDER; A Little Bit of the French Renegade in Red Hook

body: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast. Opera ''ALCINA.'' Baroque opera, especially the works of Handel, have become a specialty of the New York City Opera. Its audiences can't get enough of them. So there are many reasons to welcome the new production
title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE

body: During peak hours on weekdays, it is a 15-minute wait for one of the Staten Island ferries to heave into the terminal. Even during the sparsely traveled witching hours -- 2 or 3 o'clock in the morning -- a ferry chugs along every hour. But for a new ferry to show up in the city, you need patience. Decades of patience. The wait is over. It looks
title: To Staten Island, via Wisconsin; First Ferry Built Since 1986 Is Set to Be Christened

body: Brooklyn residents who want to sink the 3.5-mile elevated stretch of the Gowanus Expressway underground got a chill last month when they learned that the state's Department of Transportation had designated $344 million to shore up the existing structure. The money will go toward resurfacingthe road, which state officials said isnecessary for
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SOUTH BROOKLYN; The State Patches Up a Road That Residents Want to Ditch

body: WHEN the economy slows, the restaurants retreat. Except for a few publicity-seeking barkers who choose a slow moment to hawk their Kobe beef hot dogs and caviar burritos, the luxury ingredients have largely given way to the basics: pizza, burgers, sandwiches and the rest. Still, it would not be New York if restaurateurs did not apply at least a
title: $25 AND UNDER; Meeting Low Expectations, Happily

body: All dates are subject to change. September DANCENOW/NYC -- The intention of this sprawling series is to celebrate dance and the community, as its founders put it. But as it has grown, over nine years, Dancenow has become unpredictably fringy. It also serves as an unpretentious guide to what is happening in dance south of 14th Street. The
title: THE NEW SEASON/DANCE; Dancing Onstage, Out of Doors, Even in a Dream

body: A front-page article on Aug. 17 about an old lightship that sank off Red Hook, Brooklyn, mislocated Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., where the ship was once tied to a bulkhead. It is south of the Tappan Zee Bridge, not north.
title: Corrections

body: Minutes after New York City lost its power on Aug. 14, streams of raw sewage began to flow into surrounding waterways. By the time electricity was restored, 490 million gallons had spilled -- 145 million gallons from the city's largest pumping station, on the Lower East Side -- causing beaches to close and posing health and environmental hazards.
title: Sewage Spill During the Blackout Exposed a Lingering City Problem

body: Even in these days of computer games, conditioned air and liability lawsuits, the people of New York still go to the roof. They charge through security doors and climb up fire escapes, and nervous landlords or busybody building superintendents are no match. They go seeking cool relief, a little conversation, the spectacular belvedere from what
title: On the Roof, Another New York, Above It All

body: In the middle of a large, empty playground, just down the street from a strip of engineering businesses and industrial parts manufacturers in Red Hook, Brooklyn, a farm is beginning to take shape on top of the buckling pavement. It is not yet much to look at: just a few raised beds amid the weeds sprouting between the cracks in the ground. But the
title: No Red Barn, but That's a Farm in Red Hook; Two Acres, No Mule, but an Agricultural Education for Urban Teenagers

body: One morning last week, Zoe Klein, a 24-year-old circus performer from Brooklyn, stood practicing her act, which involved swinging a pair of tethered balls, and stared out to the Hudson River. ''Growing up in New York, I always felt boxed in,'' she said. ''I always knew we were surrounded by water, but it always felt dirty or inaccessible.''
title: Going Near the Water; Renovation Efforts Reclaim the City's Forbidden Shoreline

body: That innate New York City spirit of braving dark streets and other blackout crucibles spread to the city's beaches yesterday, embodied by a Speedo-clad Valeri Jadov, who refused to let a little waste spillage ruin his fun. As officials continued to test the recreational waters around the city for bacteria, the public remained barred from the water
title: THE BLACKOUT: POLLUTION; Options Few for Swimmers as Sewage Taints Waters Off Most Beaches

body: ON the Warehouse Pier in Red Hook, they talk about the day the ship sank. It's hard not to: the ship is still there, masts and a few inches of funnel sticking at odd angles out of the oily water next to the rusted skeleton of the old Revere Sugar dock. This was around 1997. They'd been watching it sink for weeks, little by little. A door in the
title: A Long Voyage To the Bottom Of Erie Basin

body: SO a rabbi, a psychiatrist and a reporter are kayaking around Long Island, when all of a sudden a giant wave knocks them into Atlantic Ocean. After bobbing to the surface the psychiatrist spots the rabbi floundering in the water, and cries, ''Rabbi! Rabbi! Can you float alone?'' And the rabbi shouts back, ''Doctor! This is no time to talk
title: Paddling Around the Island in a Kayak

body: Fires started by candles and generators during the power blackout led to one of the busiest nights since the 1970's for the New York Fire Department, officials said yesterday. There were also sporadic failures of the department's emergency medical service dispatch system. Two people died in fires in Brooklyn and Manhattan, and one person in
title: THE BLACKOUT: FIRES; Three Are Killed as Blazes Erupt Across the Northeast

body: The Swedish home furnishings retailer Ikea opened a 375,000-square- foot store last week in Paramus, N.J., as part of an expansion that will add 50 stores in North America over the next decade. The new store is the latest change in the sprawling retail landscape that has made Paramus synonymous with suburban shopping and heavy auto traffic. Ikea's
title: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- New Jersey; New Impetus for Even More Retailing in Paramus

body: ''Red Hook Bakery,'' the name of a fictitious establishment -- painted 1950's style and featuring a jolly-faced baker and beaming couple along with baked goodies including wedges of cherry pie and chocolate layer cake -- enlivens a facade of 64 West Ninth Street, a new industrial-style rental building in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn. The $4.7
title: POSTINGS: 64 West Ninth Street in Red Hook, Brooklyn; A New Industrial-Style Rental: 26 Lofts On Onetime Bakery Site

body: WHEN Chris Carnabuci first struck out on his own as a furniture designer and maker a decade ago in Manhattan, he longed for a large studio. Instead, Mr. Carnabuci, then 29, did his hammering and sawing in a one-bedroom apartment on the Upper East Side. But now Mr. Carnabuci has found his dream space in Peekskill, a once gritty town that has now
title: COMMUNITIES; In Revitalizing, Towns Aim to Lure Artists as Trailblazers

body: The baguette, says Noel Labat Comess, is the fruit fly of bread. Its life span is abbreviated, an eight-hour rocket ride from exquisite to over the hill. That is one reason why Mr. Comess built his bakery close to Manhattan. And Manhattan is one reason his business will long outlive a baguette. This year, Mr. Comess expects his Tom Cat Bakery to do
title: Enjoy That Danish. It's Lifting the City's Employment Rate.

body: THE seven members of MADE, a young architectural firm in Red Hook, Brooklyn, were sitting in their office working two weeks ago. The office is a makeshift metal shed inside a woodworking shop in a 19th-century brick warehouse. It looks more like a trailer parked on a job site than an architectural office. ''I mean, we got an office when we needed
title: Tackling Architecture With a Table Saw

Thursdays through Saturdays and Mondays at 8 p.m., and Sundays at 7 p.m. Through July 26. Tickets, $19. Information: (212) 627-2961. author: Helene Stapinski is the author of ''Five-Finger Discount.''
body: THE first time I heard one was 6:15 on a bright spring morning. I sat straight up in bed and looked out the window. Why on earth was there a helicopter outside my sixth-floor bedroom? Not just passing but hovering, like a two-ton dragonfly. Was the president visiting the Red Hook container port in Brooklyn, not far from our apartment? Was the city
title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; Stop Hovering!

body: Pretty soon, a 1-year-old harp seal that became the talk of Red Hook is expected to paddle onto Long Island Sound, leaving behind its celebrity in Brooklyn for a life of anonymity in open waters. For years, runners and fishermen have reported glimpsing just such a seal sliding through the Gowanus Canal and its nearby bay. Many scoffed at the
title: A Brooklyn Seal's Trick: Surviving the Gowanus

body: Principal's Public Death, Family's Private Grief He had been seen as a role model for school principals even before he walked into the midst of a gun battle among three teenagers near his Brooklyn elementary school. And when one of their stray bullets killed Patrick Daly, his professional reputation spread still further as his violent death was
title: FOLLOWING UP

body: A former city councilman from Brooklyn was sentenced to four years and four months in prison after petitioning a federal judge for mercy yesterday and apologizing for his part in a bribery and extortion scheme that he called ''the biggest mistake of my life.'' The former two-term councilman, Angel Rodriguez, a Democrat who represented Red Hook, was
title: Ex-Councilman Sentenced To 4 Years in Bribery Case

Sponsored by the Battery Park City Parks Conservancy. Information: (212) 267-9700. SUNSET SINGING CIRCLE, Robert F. Wagner Jr. Park Pavilions, Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan.

body: A Fable That Soars An adult looking at a child's drawing rarely sees what the young artist intends. The image that looks like a hat to a grown-up may be, in the child's words, ''a boa constrictor having swallowed an elephant.'' It is this exact misunderstanding that leads the narrator of ''The Little Prince'' to give up drawing -- that is, until,
title: FAMILY FARE

body: THERE are 120 acres of the Brooklyn waterfront that Sabato F. Catucci calls his own. The big orange and red containers, the huge forklifts, the warehouses, the enormous wood-paneled office with leather furniture and the collection of carved bald eagles are spread around him like toys. This is Mr. Catucci's world. It has been his world for more than
title: PUBLIC LIVES; For King of Brooklyn Docks, It's All About Family

body: For seven years, Awilda Vazquez was treading water on welfare, struggling to raise her two daughters, but then she got her big chance, landing a job as a $30,000-a-year clerk in the New York Fire Department. But Ms. Vazquez, of Red Hook, Brooklyn, worries that she will soon land back on the welfare rolls because she was one of the 2,000 people who
title: From Work To Welfare Reversal Seen In City Layoffs

body: My favorite thing in Montero's is the little working model of a steam engine, greasy and coated with dust, on a ledge up above where the cigarette machine used to be. It's a foot high, 18 inches or so long, jet black, with six vertical pistons. Flick the switch hidden behind the black-and-white photograph of the two Danish seamen standing outside
title: MY BROOKLYN; A Raffish Reminder, Landlubbers, of Saltier Days

body: Jackie Robinson Park is green and beautiful, fixed up over the last few years by Michael Scott Lytle, a city gardener, and a squad of volunteers. But as Mr. Lytle walks the park, a narrow strip of land in Harlem, his heart breaks every few steps, as he sees his losses rather than his victories. For him, every dead rose is like a death in the
title: Green Thumbs Versus Sticky Fingers; Gardeners Rescue Parks Beset by Theft and Neglect

body: When Charlene De Luca leaves her ancestral brownstone in Carroll Gardens in July, Brooklyn will be 725 pairs of shoes poorer. That's O.K., because her sister Paula, who lives down the street, has 1,100 pairs and no immediate plans to leave the neighborhood. The Brooklyn Shoe Sisters, though divided by Charlene's forthcoming move to Florida with her
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROLL GARDENS; Footnotes: Two Sisters Have Hundreds of Shoes With Which to Mark Their Days

body: Increases in bus service in New York City have failed to keep pace with the rise in bus ridership over the last six years, according to an analysis of New York City Transit data by the Straphangers Campaign, a watchdog group. In a report to be released today, the group says it found that average weekday ridership in the five boroughs grew by 25
title: Bus Ridership Is Outpacing Gains in Service, Report Says

body: In 1937, when Frank Sacco opened Frank's Department Store on Union Street near Columbia Street, he could not have predicted that he would one day have as a neighbor a snack bar with the trendy made-up name of Schnäk. Schnäk, which opened on Friday, is the latest business to arrive in the Columbia Street district, an area whose heart is the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RED HOOK; On a Street That Once Bustled, New Shops and Bakeries Blossom

body: The city has hired a consultant to study uses for approximately 100 acres of Red Hook waterfront that now serve as Brooklyn's last active port, raising the possibility that the site will become a park, a museum or luxury housing. In February, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the city's Economic Development Corporation hired
title: Leaseholders at Brooklyn Port Worry What Study May Bring

body: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement. body: More than 16,000 New York City children have demanded transfers out of failing public schools under a federal law that gives parents the right to request that their child be moved to a better-performing school, the city's Department of Education said yesterday. A spokesman for Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said that the department had received
title: Over 16,000 Seek Transfers From Failing City Schools

author: Randal C. Archibold, Charles V. Bagli, Al Baker, David W. Chen, Nichole M. Christian, Steven Greenhouse, David M. Herszenhorn, Kirk Johnson, Randy Kennedy, David Kocieniewski, Andy Newman, Michelle O'Donnell, Lydia Polgreen, William K. Rashbaum, Susan Sachs, Daniel J. Wakin and Robert F. body: As the United States wages war on Iraq, New Yorkers and others across the region are witnessing an extraordinary state of heightened security. Police officers are armed like assault troops outside prominent buildings, police boats are combing the waterfronts and trucks are being inspected at bridges and tunnels. Some of these unsettling sights and
title: A NATION AT WAR: NEW YORK; A Security Blanket, but With No Guarantees

body: THE phone lines to Baghdad were jammed last week. But not much ever got said over these wires, which have been more a tool of surveillance than of communication since Saddam Hussein's Baath Party took power in 1968. Conversations between Iraqis in New York and Iraqis in Baghdad have typically gone something like this: New York: ''How are you?''
title: Muffled Voices

body: ON a sparkling Tuesday morning last week, just across the harbor from the gap in Manhattan's skyline, Kevin McCabe's team was trying to prevent another Sept. 11. Mr. McCabe, the chief customs inspector for the New York and New Jersey seaport, gestured across the wind-swept water. ''The towers were right there,'' he said. ''It was like you could
title: Their Mission: Intercepting Deadly Cargo

body: The police yesterday arrested the man they believe fatally shot two undercover detectives on Staten Island on Monday night, bringing to six the number of young men being held in connection with the killings and ending a furious manhunt that took investigators as far as Pennsylvania and Maryland. The defendant, Ronell Wilson, 20, who the police said
title: Man Accused of Pulling Trigger Faces First-Degree Murder Counts in Detectives' Killings

body: Monday morning, and Jennifer Logan's second graders are banging tambourines, shaking maracas and chanting their rhyme of the day: If you can spell thing, you can spell sting. If you can spell sting, you can spell ring. If you can spell ring, you can spell spring. If you can spell spring, you can spell bring. B-R-I-N-G, cha-cha-cha! This is a
title: A Living Lab for the City's New Curriculum

body: Morgan Taylor was standing in a hotel room on Union Square about 8:30 p.m. when he first heard the name of his friend Norah Jones announced as a winner Sunday night at the Grammy Awards. It would not be the last time. Over the next three hours, Ms. Jones, 23, would complete her transformation from an arty jazz-house favorite to a bona fide pop
title: Voice From a Scruffy Bar, Now Heard Everywhere

body: Two weeks after he was selected as the New York State Assembly's deputy speaker, Clarence Norman Jr., the Brooklyn assemblyman and head of the Democratic Party organization in Brooklyn, still seemed dazzled by his new title. ''It puts me at the head of the table of power within the Assembly,'' Mr. Norman said, before shifting to the first-person
title: Brooklyn's Democratic Leader Hopes New Clout in Assembly Gets Him Over a Rough Patch

body: Last year, debate over whether to put a Fairway supermarket in Red Hook landed a Brooklyn councilman in jail for attempted bribery. The Fairway is moving in, but Red Hook, like other parts of Brooklyn on the waterfront, is still the scene of skirmishes involving developers who envision lucrative lofts with river views, residents who worry about
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RED HOOK; Warehouse Is an Emblem Of Newest Waterfront Battles

body: On Tiffany Place in Red Hook, Brooklyn, 12 condominium units carved from a 1920's industrial structure are being sold as their developer begins to convert a neighboring 1860's factory building to 36 apartments. The transformation continues the transition of an old industrial area to residential use. A two-story industrial building that sits between
title: Residential Real Estate; A Red Hook Renewal on Tiffany Place

body: After more than two centuries under federal control, Governors Island is expected to be returned to New York today, several public officials said yesterday. The ceremony at the White House this morning designating the official return of the island will cap eight years of off-again-on-again negotiations over the future of the 172-acre piece of land,
title: White House to Hand Over Governors Island to New York

author: Adam Fifield collaborated with Wayne Barrett on ''Rudy! An Investigative Biography of Rudolph Giuliani.''
body: ON a slate-gray afternoon at a Midtown construction site, seven men in hard hats and yellow rain gear stepped into a steel cage suspended over a dark hole nearly 60 stories deep. The last man on board latched the door shut, and the cage sank away from daylight and toward a sonorous, mechanical roar far below. The men inserted earplugs and then
title: The Underground Men

author: Steve Kurutz is an editor at Details.
body: AS savvy New Yorkers will tell you, the streets of Chinatown are rife with bargains: Prada bags for mere peanuts, CD players at eight-track prices. But Chrissy Piper, a 30-year-old photographer from Red Hook, Brooklyn, has found a deal that beats them all. Since June, Ms. Piper has taken an express bus from Manhattan's Chinatown to the Chinatown in
title: URBAN TACTICS; Enter the Dragon Coach

body: AS NEW YORK confronts momentous questions -- about the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan, its budget woes, the danger of terrorism, the prospect of the Olympics in 2012 -- there is no shortage of predictions on where the city is headed in the next few decades. To peer into the future, the City section has consulted a dozen historians, sociologists,
title: New York's Tomorrow: 12 Visions

body: Forget those sweatshirts that say ''Brooklyn,'' or, even worse, ''New York.'' Michael de Zayas is here to help you announce to the world through your sweatshirt that you are from one particular neighborhood, one street or, if you want to get really specific, one address. Mr. de Zayas, 28, is the president and sole employee of Neighborhoodies, a
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK GARB; Your 'Hood on Your Chest, Your Heart on Your Sleeve
